description:
Up until now, we've just supplied `scene.render()` with a fname to signify that we want it to save an image to disk.  However, there are times when you may want to render a scene (which by default returns an `ImageArray` object) without saving to disk, or you want the scene to automatically generate a filename to which it should save a rendering.  This is impossible in the current system.  So now I've added the `.save()` method to scene for saving renderings to disk, which will automatically figure out a relevant filename if you do not provide one.  I updated the tests and the docs to reflect this change.

So now the relevant means of generating an image:


```
#!python

sc = yt.create_scene(ds)
<do stuff to scene>
sc.render(sigma_clip=4)
sc.save()
```


* Adding scene.save() function which saves an image to disk after it has been rendered.

* Adding in automatic recognition of png files in save() method on scene

* Adding log messages to renderings.

* Updating use of sc.render() to incorporate sc.save() when required.

* Updating docs to use the new sc.render(); sc.save(fname) paradigm.

* Updating VR narrative docs to explicitly tell user how to render and save.  Also discusses sigma_clip

* Adding examples to volume_rendering narrative docs for saving images.

Addresses Issues #1099 and #1109.

UPDATE1: Corrected some problems in my merge with Nathan's last PR.

UPDATE2: Removed progress bar.

UPDATE3: Made opaque only renderings have better default filename
title: [experimental] Modifying scene.render() function to not save to disk and instead requiring sc.save()

content.raw: I think you're right, but I wanted to give the user an idea that progress was being made since this can sometimes be a long operation.  I know it won't update but at least it conveys that this is a slow step.  Prior to this, it was just sitting there and you couldn't tell if the code froze or what.
content.html: I think you're right, but I wanted to give the user an idea that progress was being made since this can sometimes be a long operation. I know it won't update but at least it conveys that this is a slow step. Prior to this, it was just sitting there and you couldn't tell if the code froze or what.

content.raw: Sorry I didn't catch this PR. I'm -1 on removing fname from the scene.render() function, and I think the sigma_clip should happen during the save(), and not during the render().  The save() functionality is great though.
content.html: Sorry I didn't catch this PR. I'm -1 on removing fname from the scene.render() function, and I think the sigma_clip should happen during the save(), and not during the render(). The save() functionality is great though.

pullrequest.title: [experimental] Modifying scene.render() function to not save to disk and instead requiring sc.save()

content.raw: The new PR swaps the `sigma_clip` to the `save()` function, so that one can render once and then save with lots of different `sigma_clip` values with minimal computational overhead.  As far as keeping the fname in the `scene.render()`, what do you mean?  So that if you `sc.render(fname=fname)`, it still saves to disk without the need of `sc.save()`?  I just thought we wanted to be fully explicit about each step we were taking, so `render()` actually runs the radiative transfer, and then `save()` sends it to disk.
content.html: The new PR swaps the sigma_clip to the save() function, so that one can render once and then save with lots of different sigma_clip values with minimal computational overhead. As far as keeping the fname in the scene.render(), what do you mean? So that if you sc.render(fname=fname), it still saves to disk without the need of sc.save()? I just thought we wanted to be fully explicit about each step we were taking, so render() actually runs the radiative transfer, and then save() sends it to disk.
